analytic.title: On Applying Spatial Constraints in Fuzzy Image Clustering Using a Fuzzy Rule-Based System

div.p: In this letter, a novel approach for enhancing the results of fuzzy clustering by imposing spatial constraints for solving image segmentation problems is presented. We have developed a Sugeno-type rule-based system [9] with three inputs and 11 rules that interacts with the clustering results obtained by the well-known FCM and/or PCM algorithms. It provides good image segmentations in terms of region smoothness and elimination of the effects of noise. The results of the proposed rule-based neighborhood enhancement (RB-NE) system are compared to well-known segmentation algorithms using stochastic field modeling. They are found to be of comparable quality, while being of lower computational complexity.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A CCORDING to Haralick [1], a good image segmenta- tion consists of well defined regions that consistently describe intensity variations within the same object. In addition, there should be no single-pixel regions-the effects of noise-within bigger regions and the segmented regions' boundaries should be smooth. These requirements cannot be met using the well known K-means, fuzzy c-Means (FCM) [2] and possibilistic c-means (PCM) [3] algorithms due to the lack of spatial constraints in the calculation of the fuzzy (or crisp) partition matrix. Therefore, many algorithms have been presented in the literature that impose spatial constraints to clustering algorithms for segmenting image data. These algorithms are mainly based on stochastic field modeling of the problem and use single-or multiresolution approaches to enhance the quality of image segmentations [4]- [6]. Some fuzzy approaches that impose similar constraints have also appeared recently [7], [8].

In this work, we have developed a rule-based fuzzy system that postprocesses the clustering results of any fuzzy clustering algorithm by imposing spatial continuity constraints and using the inherent correlation of an eight-connected neighborhood. In Section II, we describe the rule based system and the underlying concepts for its' development; in Section III we provide some experimental results and finally, in Section IV we discuss the results of our approach.

div.head: II. THE FUZZY RULEBASE FOR ENHANCEMENT OF CLUSTERING RESULTS
A. Definitions
div.p: The main concept in imposing spatial constraints is to add a neighborhood voting scheme that increases or decreases the possibility of the central pixel to belong to a certain region according to the region labels/memberships of its' neighbors. The overall region membership assignment is given by combining this voting scheme with a proper distance metric between the data and a prototype value.

In the proposed approach, imposing spatial constraints is based on a voting scheme over a neighborhood, that is evaluated on a cluster basis. The application of a generic fuzzy clustering scheme, e.g., FCM or PCM, to an image data set provides a fuzzy partition matrix of dimensions where is the number of clusters, and with being the image dimensions, that describes the degree of membership of each pixel to the cluster according to a distance metric that relates to i.e. the cluster prototypes.

div.head: B. Imposing Spatial Constraints
div.p: The basic criterion for imposing spatial constraints over a neighborhood is that when we deal with a homogeneous region, either of low or high membership to a cluster, the fuzzy partition matrix should be updated in such a way that describes the membership of the majority of the pixel neighbors to the cluster. The region homogeneity is controlled by DUMAX. When DUMAX is low, it suggests that there are no discontinuities in the neighborhood that is examined. div.head: III. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
div.p: In this section, the results obtainable from the proposed system are presented. We have applied the RB-NE system to the fuzzy partition matrix obtained by using FCM for clustering the Lena image to two and five clusters, using only the pixel intensities as features. The fuzzy partition matrix was randomly initialized, the fuzzifier was set to two and the termination criterion was a change of 10 in the cost function [2]. In Fig. 2(a) and (c), the results of the adaptive clustering scheme (ACS) proposed by Pappas [4] for two and five clusters, respectively, are shown. In Fig. 2(b) and(d), the results of the proposed scheme are shown. The results of RB-NE are quite similar with ACS. This observation is rather encouraging, having in mind the computational complexity of ACS and other similar schemes. In order to understand the effects of the proposed scheme, we plot in Fig. 3 the elements of the fuzzy partition matrix that correspond to the vertical centerline of the Lena image that were obtained by the FCM algorithm (for the "bright" cluster) in dotted line, and the correction term that resulted from the application of the proposed scheme in solid line. Note that RB-NE leaves homogeneous regions practically unaffected, while modifying the membership in their boundaries and reducing the membership in regions of low membership. The application of RB-NE to the "dark" cluster would produce the contrary effects in the case of two clusters. In both cases, the value of was set to 0.1, a selection that was made in order to guarantee considerable increase (decrease) in cluster membership when the majority of the neighborhood certainly belongs (not belongs) to the cluster.

div.head: IV. CONCLUSION
div.p: We have shown how a fuzzy rule-based system can be designed in order to impose spatial constraints on the results of generic clustering algorithms in the framework of image segmentation. The proposed system performs equally well when compared to other methodologies for solving the same problem, e.g., the Gibbs random field models. The proposed system was inspired by the operation of two-point clique potentials that are used to model Gibbs probability density functions and apply spatial constraints [4] that are the key element of their efficiency. However, RB-NE is intuitively simple and its computational complexity is lower since it is not iterative and requires the evaluation of the fuzzy rules once per pixel. It has also provided better results for the class of images examined when compared to generic fuzzy data clustering algorithms.
